p.s: The article Language learning in the UK can't, won't, don't, written by John Worne, was published 2015 in the newspaper The Telegraph.
The topic of the article is learning of a Foreignforeign language in the UK In the following the way how Worne presents his view, by using communicative strategies, will be analysed.
John Worne uses many aspects to present his view and to influence the reader.
the use of (they don't) or in line 14-15 the next generation of wearable tech will enable cultural telepathy anyway Cobblers.
By using this comments the author refutes counter-arguments and expresses his view about the topic.
Furthermore that comments should influence the reader and brings him/her to think about the subject.
Another aspect of the author's strategies are enumerations.
Worne uses them to name advantages of learning other languages.
You find an example in l. 17-18: Languages are essential for our trade, prosperity, cultural exports, diplomacy and national security.
This enumeration describes diverse problems for the UKin the future and one of these results concerns everybody.
Nobody wants a loss of prosperity or national security.
The extreme results are good arguments for learning foreign languages and for the author's view.
the enumeration should bring the reader to overthink his position, if he is against learning of other languages.
Moreover the article mentions concrete examples for learning foreign languages.
For instance in 27-29: The tough reality in a tough jobs market is a lawyer with Chinese language skills is more in demand than a pure lawyer or a pure linguist.
Examples like that describe the huge advantages for multilingual persons.
In addition to that the author mentions disadvantages: UK business would hire people abroad, because they speak more languages than home-grown talents.
This example influence the reader, because the reader sees eotjer advantages fpr jos/her life or disadvantages that could influence the readers life tremendously.
To sum up everything you can say that the author uses many diverse strategies to convince the reader of his view.
